"It is so difficult to buy them," Stella says. "Our daily life is not easy already and why should we make things harder for ourselves?"

articles.title: Video shows Maduro's arrival in US and journey into custody
articles.body:
Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife Cilia Flores have been placed in custody at a New York detention centre after he was captured during US strikes on Caracas.

Footage shows a handcuffed Maduro emerging from a plane after it landed at Stewart Air National Guard Base in New York state on Saturday evening.

He was then taken to the offices of the US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA). The White House shared a video of him at the office on social media, with the caption: "Perp walked."

He was later taken into a helicopter at a New York heliport, which is believed to have transported him and Flores to the Metropolitan Detention Center, a federal facility in Brooklyn where they are being held.

articles.title: 'I'm so happy' - Venezuelans in the US react to Maduro's capture
articles.body:
US President Donald Trump says the US launched strikes on Venezuela and captured its President Nicolás Maduro.

The BBC's Bernd Debusmann Jr reports from Doral, Florida, a hub for the Venezuelan and Venezuelan-American community in the US.

articles.title: Trump on Venezuela: 'We are going to run the country'
articles.body:
President Donald Trump announced that the US will run Venezuela until a 'proper transition can take place.'

The United States launched strikes against the country and captured Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro and his wife on 3 January.

Trump said Maduro and his wife were captured from a fortress-like house and will be taken to New York; the president said there were "a few injuries but no deaths on our side".

Maduro was indicted in New York on drugs and weapons charges, Attorney General Pam Bondi said, adding Maduro will "face the full wrath of American justice on American soil in American courts".

Venezuela declared a national emergency, denouncing "extremely serious military aggression".

articles.title: Footage shows attack at La Guaira port
articles.body:
Port La Guaira is Caracas' main conduit to the Caribbean Sea, located in Miranda state.

Footage filmed nearby shows flames and several plumes of smoke rising.

Read more on our live page.

articles.title: Watch: Over 100 firefighters on the scene of Denver blaze
articles.body:
The Colorado city of Denver was lit up by enormous fire on Friday evening, with over 100 firefighters on the scene to battle the blaze.

Fire department officials said there were initial concerns that the "five-alarm fire" could spread to other nearby homes or businesses, but first responders were able to keep the flames contained.

No injuries have been reported as a result of the fire, which occurred at an apartment block that was still under construction.

articles.title: Watch: Four men rescued from boat teetering on dam edge
articles.body:
Footage shows the moment four men were pulled to safety after spending hours dangling off the edge of a 40m (130ft) dam in South Africa.

Rescuers from the National Sea Rescue Institute (NSRI) arrived at the Grootdraai Dam in Mpumalanga on Monday after reports that a boat had suffered motor failure, before drifting to the edge of the dam.

The NSRI credited quick-thinking employees who opened sluice gates on the spillway to stop the boat being swept away by the heavy water flow. The men were reportedly uninjured.

articles.title: Watch: Moment 400-pound runaway prop injures Disney employee
articles.body:
Footage shows the moment a worker at Walt Disney World was injured after being hit by a 400-lb (180kg) runaway fake boulder prop.

The incident took place at the Indiana Jones Epic Stunt Spectacular! during a live recreation of a famous scene from the film.

Video shows the boulder rolling towards the audience as a staff member jumps into its path, preventing it from reaching the crowd.

The staff member did not appear to stand up immediately, and other workers are seen running to his side. The Florida theme park said they are supporting the staff member, who is now recovering.

Read the full story on the incident at Walt Disney World here.

articles.title: Steve Rosenberg: What are Russians hoping for in 2026?
articles.body:
As the New Year holiday gets underway, the BBC's Russia editor Steve Rosenberg asks people on the streets of Moscow about their hopes for 2026 and how they see their future.

It's not only Russia's war on Ukraine that is preying on people's minds, but also the state of the economy, which is coming under increasing pressure.
